item.title: Davos Memo: Trump and Davos: Not Exactly Best Friends, but Not Enemies Either
item.media:description: Mr. Trump arriving in Davos. “The real message is we want great prosperity and we want great peace,” he said.
item.description: Last year, the chieftains at Davos were panicked at the thought of Trump. This year, they welcomed him with somewhat open arms.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: South Korea Hospital Fire Kills at Least 37 People
item.media:description: Officials said they were still investigating the cause of a fire that engulfed Sejong Hospital in Miryang, South Korea, that killed at least 41 people.
item.description: The deadly blaze was the latest in a string of a tragedies that have heightened public concern over the country’s safety standards.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. and Pakistan Give Conflicting Accounts of Drone Strike
item.media:description: The site of a United States drone strike in northwestern Pakistan on Wednesday.
item.description: United States officials rejected a claim by Pakistan that the strike had targeted an Afghan refugee camp.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Victory in Russia Election Assured, Putin Seeks High Turnout
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with rally car drivers during a campaign stop on Thursday in Kazan, Russia.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: In his bid for another term, the Russian president is seeking the legitimacy of a contested vote without real democracy. It is a hard sell.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Deadly Fire Undermines South Korean Leader’s Vow to Make Country Safer
item.media:description: The fire that engulfed Sejong Hospital in the southern city of Miryang on Friday was the deadliest in South Korea in a decade.
item.media:credit: Kim Gu-Yeon/Kyongnamdomin Ilbo, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The fire that killed at least 37 people comes as President Moon Jae-in’s approval ratings are falling over his decision to form a unified Olympic team with North Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: A Film Has Inflamed Indians. But Moviegoers Mostly Say It’s Fine.
item.media:description: A police officer stood watch as people arrived to watch the Bollywood film “Padmaavat” at a movie theater in Hyderabad, India, on Thursday.
item.description: “Padmaavat,” a lavish new movie about a Hindu queen, had stirred up violent protests. After months of tension, the movie premiered on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, KAI SCHULTZ and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Allies or Terrorists: Who Are the Kurdish Fighters in Syria?
item.media:description: Mourners carry the coffins of civilians and military personnel killed in Afrin, Syria, during the Turkish offensive launched last weekend.
item.description: United States cooperation with the Kurdish group has complicated ties with Turkey, which views them as terrorists.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Doomsday Clock Is Set at 2 Minutes to Midnight, Closest Since 1950s
item.media:description: From left, Sivan Kartha, a senior scientist at the Stockholm Environmental Institute; Lawrence M. Krauss, director of the Arizona State University Origins Project; Robert Rosner, a theoretical physicist at the University of Chicago; and Sharon A. Squassoni, research professor at George Washington University, at a news conference in Washington on Thursday to announce that the Doomsday Clock had been set to two minutes to midnight.
item.description: The “clock,” kept by the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, is a symbolic measurement of scientists’ concerns about disaster.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: China Embraces a Game About a Traveling Frog
item.description: For whatever reason, Travel Frog, an extremely low-key Japanese mobile game, is a hit in China. “You don’t even need to think about anything,” one player explained.
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Davos, Dreamers, Doomsday: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Davos Lauds China’s Climate Efforts Even as Emissions Rise
item.media:description: The Wujing Coal-Electricity Power Station in Shanghai in 2017. China’s electricity consumption jumped 6.6 percent last year. Wind and solar energy grew quickly, but not nearly enough to meet the extra demand.
item.description: An economic upturn led to rising fossil-fuel emissions after two years of drops, showing the task Beijing faces in fulfilling its climate promises.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and LISA FRIEDMAN

item.title: In Davos, Trump’s Isolationism May Isolate Him
item.description: Several world leaders highlighted integration and cooperation as vital for the global economy ahead of President Trump’s arrival at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

item.title: The World Bank Is Remaking Itself as a Creature of Wall Street
item.media:description: Jim Yong Kim, president of the World Bank. “One of the most difficult things to do in a large bureaucracy is to change incentives,” he said.
item.media:credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York
item.description: Jim Yong Kim, the World Bank’s president, is trying to revitalize a hidebound institution. But his embrace of Wall Street is controversial.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.

item.title: Ivory Coast Arrests Six in Ring That Smuggled Parts of Elephants, Leopards and Pangolins
item.media:description: Ivory Coast’s minister of water and forests, Alain-Richard Donwahi, center, examined seized elephant ivory with other Ivorian officials at the headquarters of the country’s Transnational Organized Crime Unit in Abidjan on Thursday.
item.description: The crackdown follows another major bust of an ivory trafficking network in Gabon
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Eco Activists for Governance and Law Enforcement (Eagle Network)

item.title: 10 Monkeys and a Beetle: Inside VW’s Campaign for ‘Clean Diesel’
item.media:description: Testing a Volkswagen Golf in California in September 2015. That month, the carmaker admitted that it had installed illegal software to help its cars evade standards on diesel emissions.
item.description: An experiment that produced false data sheds light on how German automakers financed scientific research to promote their political agenda.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.category: European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector

item.title: A Beginner’s Travel Guide to Haiti, El Salvador and Africa
item.media:description: A view of Fort des Oliviers in southern Haiti.
item.media:credit: Christopher Miller for The New York Times
item.description: With recent reported inflammatory comments, President Trump put the spotlight on places many Americans have never visited. Here are some travel recommendations on a few of those countries.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN SABLICH

item.title: Theresa May Arrives in Davos as U.K.’s Post-‘Brexit’ Slide Continues
item.media:description: Theresa May, Britain’s prime minister, speaking on Thursday. “As we leave the European Union,” she said, “the U.K. will continue to be a global advocate of free trade.”
item.description: Britain’s stature as a global economic power has lessened since it voted to leave the European Union. Mrs. May’s speech at the World Economic Forum, and the reception to it, underscored that reality.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Davos Memo: For Mnuchin, a Lesson in How Words Can Move Markets
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on a panel with Christine Lagarde, the chief of the International Monetary Fund, in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday.
item.description: Steven Mnuchin, whose apparently offhand remark on the dollar caused a tumble, joins many Treasury secretaries whose words have been given more meaning than intended.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Guinobatan Journal: A Volcano Known for Its Beauty Is Also a Killer
item.media:description: The Mayon volcano spewing ash and lava in Albay Province, the Philippines, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: More than 70,000 people in the Philippines have been forced to evacuate after Mount Mayon, a volcano admired for its symmetry, showed signs of erupting.
item.dc:creator: JES AZNAR and RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Trump, in Davos, Mends Split With Britain and Widens One With Palestinians
item.media:description: President Trump met Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday.
item.description: The president tried to smooth friction with Britain in a meeting with Theresa May, while excoriating the Palestinians in a sit-down with Israel’s Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: U.S. Plans to Send First Aircraft Carrier to Vietnam Since War’s End
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Thursday.
item.description: The proposed trip, expected in March, comes amid warming ties between the two countries and heightened tensions over China’s territorial claims.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Train Derails Near Milan, Killing at Least 3 and Injuring Dozens
item.media:description: Derailed carriages in Pioltello, on the outskirts of Milan, on Thursday.
item.description: Officials are investigating the causes of the crash, which took out the two central carriages of the commuter service.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Ontario’s Opposition Leader Quits Over Sexual Misconduct Allegations
item.media:description: Patrick Brown, the leader of the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario, has been accused of sexual misconduct.
item.media:credit: Rural Ontario Municipal Association, via Twitter
item.description: Patrick Brown’s resignation threw the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario into disarray after two women said he made advances on them when they were teenagers.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER and IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Letter 42: Australia Day’s Multicultural Significance
item.media:description: Centenary Square, built in 1888 to mark the British arrival in Parramatta 100 years earlier.
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.description: Is the holiday a time when people of all backgrounds feel they belong or a day that celebrates colonization without regard for the colonized?
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Australia Diary: Should Australia Commemorate White Settlement?
item.media:description: Centenary Square, built in 1888 to mark the British arrival in Parramatta 100 years earlier.
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.description: A diverse group of Australians in western Sydney add their voices to the debate over colonization and Australia Day, the country’s biggest holiday.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Draghi, Chief of Europe’s Central Bank, Chides Mnuchin Over Dollar Comments
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, in November. Rapidly changing economic conditions have made his remarks from even just a month ago seem obsolete.
item.description: Mr. Draghi’s critique of comments by the U.S. Treasury secretary came as the eurozone central bank tried to quash speculation about an early end to its economic stimulus program.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Trump Sharply Warns Turkey Against Military Strikes in Syria
item.media:description: Turkish tanks stationed near the Syrian border on Wednesday.
item.description: In a phone call, President Trump urged President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to limit attacks against Kurdish militias, including some backed by American forces.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Citing ‘Whitewash,’ Bill Richardson Quits Rohingya Post
item.media:description: Bill Richardson in Yangon, Myanmar, on Wednesday. He said Myanmar’s civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, had “developed an arrogance of power.”
item.description: Former Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a longtime friend of Myanmar’s leader, quit an advisory panel on the Rohingya crisis, calling it a “cheerleading squad.”
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH and RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Davos, Senate, Larry Nassar: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Defeated in Syria, ISIS Fighters Held in Camps Still Pose a Threat
item.media:description: A Kurdish militia member interrogating a man suspected of being a member of the Islamic State in Raqqa, Syria, in October.
item.media:credit: Afshin Ismaeli/SOPA Images, via Getty Images
item.description: American military officials fear the makeshift camps may repeat a security mistake of the Iraq war even as they have sought to avoid any major responsibility for addressing it.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Is Turkey’s Syria Offensive Endangering U.S. Troops?
item.description: Turkey's president has said he wants his forces to take the Syrian city of Manbij. The problem is that the United States is already there.

item.title: White House Urged to Restore Aid to U.N. Palestinian Refugee Agency
item.media:description: Palestinian schoolgirls in Gaza this week during the announcement of a fund-raising campaign for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.
item.description: In a letter, leaders of 21 aid organizations said they were “particularly alarmed” that the cuts announced last week appeared punitive and political.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency

item.title: Mysterious Bank Deposits Fueled Suspicion of Former C.I.A. Officer
item.media:description: Jerry Chun Shing Lee, 53, is awaiting transfer to federal court in Northern Virginia, where he was charged.
item.description: Authorities detected hundreds of thousands of dollars in unexplained deposits, but found no proof linking Jerry Chun Shing Lee to a devastating intelligence breach.
item.dc:creator: ADAM GOLDMAN and MATT APUZZO

item.title: And Then There Was One: Last Challenger to Egypt’s Sisi Drops Out
item.media:description: The Egyptian human rights lawyer Khaled Ali, right, at a news conference in Cairo on Wednesday. Mr. Ali said he would not run in Egypt’s presidential election.
item.description: Khaled Ali, the last major challenger in Egypt’s presidential race, quit the race on Wednesday, clearing the field for President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Trump Administration Slaps New Sanctions on North Korea
item.media:description: President Trump has had fiery exchanges with Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, over the past year.
item.description: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions on North Korea as the administration continues to crack down on the nuclear ambitions of Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: U.S. Drone Strike Kills Militants in Pakistan but Angers Its Government
item.media:description: The site of a United States drone strike in the Kurram tribal region of Pakistan on Wednesday.
item.description: The attack in northwestern Pakistan killed three members of the militant Haqqani network, but the government condemned it as a violation of the country’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Upending Brazil’s Presidential Race, Court Upholds Ex-Leader’s Conviction
item.media:description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil, center, speaking to supporters during a rally on Wednesday after a Brazilian appeals court upheld a corruption conviction against him.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: The decision could bar former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva from running for a third term in October, but he is expected to fight for the right to appear on the ballot.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Bottom Line for Davos Elite: Trump Is Good for Business
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Zurich this week. While many are poised to recoil at President Trump’s arrival in Davos this week, much of the moneyed elite there are willing to overlook what they portray as the president’s rhetorical foibles in favor of the additional wealth he has delivered to their coffers.
item.description: Much of the moneyed elite are willing to overlook what they portray as rhetorical foibles in favor of focusing on the additional wealth the president has delivered.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: China Will Tame Its Growing Debt Load in 3 Years, Top Xi Adviser Says
item.media:description: Liu He, an influential adviser to President Xi Jinping of China, told the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, that the country has a plan for reining in its mounting debt.
item.description: Liu He, an influential adviser to President Xi Jinping of China, pledges in a rare public appearance that Beijing will tame its debt within three years.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: In Russia, ‘The Death of Stalin’ Is No Laughing Matter
item.media:description: A poster for “The Death of Stalin” in Moscow on Tuesday, the day the Culture Ministry withdrew the film’s distribution license.
item.description: The Culture Ministry withdrew permission for the film to be shown in the country, denouncing its satirical treatment of the Soviet Union and its legacy.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW LUXMOORE

item.title: Cell Behind Barcelona Attack May Have Had Sights on Eiffel Tower
item.media:description: A memorial site in Barcelona, Spain, after the attacks in August that left 16 dead and 140 others wounded.
item.description: The assault in Spain in August, which killed 16 people and wounded 140 others, could have been far worse, according to researchers of the Program on Global Terrorism in Madrid.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Combating Terrorism Center at West Point
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Daughters of African Immigrants Use the Stage to Tell of Two Worlds
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Danai Gurira, Jocelyn Bioh, Mfoniso Udofia and Ngozi Anyanwu.
item.media:credit: Top left, Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times; other photographs by Brad Ogbonna for The New York Times
item.description: Danai Gurira, Jocelyn Bioh, Mfoniso Udofia and Ngozi Anyanwu share first-generation stories. “You can complain about how your culture is depicted,” says Ms. Anyanwu, “or you can do it yourself.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON
item.category: School Girls; Or, the African Mean Girls Play (Play)

item.title: India Braces for Opening of Film That Has Hindu Extremists Enraged
item.media:description: Indians in the city of Ahmedabad protested against “Padmaavat,” a Bollywood epic about a legendary Hindu queen said to have commited suicide rather than submit to a Muslim ruler.
item.description: Women threatened suicide. A politician offered a reward for beheading the director. The police were out in force for Thursday’s release of “Padmaavat.”
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, SUHASINI RAJ and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Botox for Camels? At Saudi Arabia Beauty Pageant, That’s a Big No-No
item.media:description: Camels at a beauty contest in Rumah, Saudi Arabia, this past week.
item.description: Illicit injections to puff up lips and cheeks have led to a raft of disqualifications at the kingdom’s prestigious annual festival.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Britain’s ‘Most Un-P.C.’ Charity Will Shut Down
item.media:description: Great Ormond Street children’s hospital in London said that it would return money raised for it by the Presidents Club Charitable Trust.
item.description: Outrage and questions in Parliament had greeted an undercover report by The Financial Times on the all-male event, which had 130 young hostesses.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Tech We’re Using: Using Drones and Netflix in the Andes, but Sidestepping Google Maps
item.media:description: Nicholas Casey, the Andes bureau chief, reading his Kindle in Medellín, Colombia, where he is based.
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.description: Nicholas Casey, Andes bureau chief for The Times, discussed the benefits of technology in many South American countries — and why Google Maps isn’t the best tool there.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Wreckage of Last Known Slave Ship in U.S. May Have Been Found
item.media:description: The remains of a ship in a muddy bank north of Mobile, Ala., this month. Some experts think it could be the Clotilda, the last slave ship documented to have delivered captive Africans to the United States.
item.description: A reporter in Alabama set out to find the remains of the Clotilda, which was set on fire in 1860 after bringing 110 slaves to the waters off Mobile, Ala.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG and NIRAJ CHOKSHI
